zuul/merger/merger.py.message: This argument doesn't seem to ever be used. We call this function on line 888 below only passing the hexsha.
True, but it matches the rest of the methods on this object, so I think it's good to have it here.  If we plumb the event through in the caller, we can add it.

I believe that will be the case, though it's still going to apply the branch matchers.  Imagine a case where a job is defined in-repo on the master branch only and has two variants, one that matches "master" and one that matches "stable".  In that case, we still need to figure out which one to run for our tag, but the configuration of those 2 variants will be determined by the state of the repo in the tag.

I think I understand your question, and it's good to be clear about this.  I have written a follow-up change with a unit test that demonstrates what happens when you change the configuration of a job on a branch, and then retroactively tag a commit before that change.  Zuul will use the newer configuration of the job (i.e., the Zuul configuration that merged after the point of the tag).  But of course, it will check out the tagged version of the repo, so the playbooks, etc, would be from that point in time.

I grant that may be unintuitive from one perspective ("just run the job as it was defined in the repo at the point of the tag"), but from others, it may be more intuitive.  Many post/tag jobs are defined centrally, and in those cases, one may not expect a tag of a repo to run with an old version of the central config.  This change keeps parity between the two approaches.

I think it will be difficult to model and implement the approach where we use the job definition at the point of the tag.  Zuul's variant selection is based on branches, and so while it may be straightforward to create a speculative layout with the contents of the tag and then identify which branches the tag is in in order to identify which variants to apply -- that speculative configuration would still interact with the *current* configuration from other repos.  We can't rewind the state of the entire system to a tag from a single repo.  It might work most of the time, but in some cases you might end up with a Zuul configuration that doesn't make sense because the delta between the tagged repo and other repos defining parent jobs, etc, is too great.

Another consideration is that on a tag it's difficult to determine whether Zuul needs to create a dynamic configuration.  One approach would be to always have Zuul create a dynamic config for tags.  That's not efficient, but it's at least possible.

I think these issues will be difficult to overcome, though we have overcome similarly difficult issues to get even to the point of this change.  I have serious doubts about whether we will be comfortable implementing that approach, particularly because of the first issue (delta between the tagged repo and others).  But If we do decide to proceed with that, I think we can make that change after this one.  In other words, I think it's a natural progression from the current state, to this change, to (if possible) the state you describe.  I don't think we will be locked into this behavior.

If possible, it would be nice to get the repository in the state it was in the tagged commit.

Then it doesn't matter which branch is matched, in regards to which job-variant to use. As long as the jobs definitions are parsed from that commit.

Hmm. Are we talking about the same thing?

I ment the job as it was defined on the tag itself (assuming the job is defined in the project with the tag). Even if the same commit exists on different branches, the branches should be identical at that commit.

When we run check and gate we want to do that on the head of the branch, but a tag we want exactly as it was, without any new features or fixes.

I believe that items[-1] is important here because it is the tail set of changes in a speculative state?

Is that worth a comment that we choose this specific item for that reason?
Yes, though this is generally not called in speculative scenarios.  It might be more accurate to just say that this is the item under test.

doc/source/admin/examples/zuul-config/zu.message: This also has clean check, why don't we remove it (and add supercedes).
This terminology doesn't really match the github workflow. Github doesn't have +- Verified votes but rather '<pipeline> status'.
Not sure if it's really needed but we typically require that the pr is open here.

@Tobias you said Zuul checks branch protection rules, then is this requirement really needed ? Within the branch protection rules "Require pull request reviews before merging" can be set and configured as well. I haven't tested btw, what do you think ?
It only checks the status part of branch protection rules, but not (yet) the review part. See https://review.opendev.org/644557 which is in review for the code review part.
I'd like to see us use 'gate' here, goes nicely with the idea of zuul.
Status requirements shouldn't generally be necessary as zuul evaluates the status branch protection rules.
Yes, imho using branch protection for this should be the best practice we should embrace.

Alright but it means that branch protection must be set to true (zuul default is false) and "Require status checks to pass before merging" is checked. Furthermore "<tenant>/check" status must be checked in the list. If not if the pr got the 'gate' tag and an approval it will enter the gate pipeline whatever the status of the check pipeline. I'm fine with that but we should explain it.

I found it useful to react on all status events. This way it's very easy to combine zuul with other github apps like WIP bot:

  - event: pull_request
    action: status
    status: .*:success

Configuring it this way makes zuul also reacting on other status bots (which might be required by the branch protection). Each positive status will trigger then the pipeline which then checks if all required status are fulfilled now (if not the change won't enter the gate anyway).

The reason we cannot unlabel here, is because we only want to unlabel if pull_request is changed. With below, zuul would unlabel 'gate' all all the triggers below like recheck / open / close.

The only way to handle it today I found, is a new pipeline. This is based on what spamaps is doing too.

doc/source/reference/tenants.rst.message: Why %TENANT% and not {tenant}?  There are many other templated strings in Zuul (not only in Ansible, but in Zuul itself, eg, success-url, and they all use python3 style substitution syntax.

I know this seems nitpicky, but this could have significant UX impact.  Take a look at the pipeline.start-message templating available.  Here's the implementation:

https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul/src/branch/master/zuul/model.py#L2694

Based on the pattern there, I'd expect to be able to use "{tenant.name}" (note lower case) as a substitution.  Unless there's a good reason to do otherwise, let's use the same format and case (and even the same methods like https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul/src/branch/master/zuul/model.py#L4476 ) to promote consistency.

specs/website-stats.rst.message: Not to be the word police, but I'd like to find a way to avoid using the term "tracking" when we talk about this. I explicitly don't want us tracking users' or visitors' PII, but folks might misunderstand if we're not careful in how we describe it. Maybe we can say "activity metrics" or something along those lines?
Raw networks can also be risky in this regard.
May be good to call out examples like people following links from internal company defect trackers or knowledge bases.
These seem somewhat less problematic but we can add them later if there's interest and we deem it safe.

Given the logs are stored on the local filesystem, the reports could be as well... the URL can be achieved simply by aliasing it to the local file location. Of course, that makes the reports themselves semi-precious and we could end up wanting to make backups of them, at which point yeah your Zuul publication job starts to sound better and better. If we were already to the point where we were using Zuul to CD all this with the server as a static node, there would be a lot less indirection involved.

Starting from the assumption that we're trying to concentrate on all our websites being served data stored on afs volumes, i don't think this is a good idea because it means that the server will have to somehow have keys to write to every site it serves.  this might be across opendev/openstack/starlingx/airship etc.

we could certainly export this to something like /afs/.openstack.org/stats.opendev.org/<hostname> and that way the static host would only need one key for that directory and could just use a local cron job.

but better still IMO would be if this was driven from zuul via periodic jobs.  I've been thinking that through a bit and proposed for the existing system

https://review.opendev.org/709382 static: Framework for periodic 404 scraping job 

In writing this, I realised it would be even better if Zuul could run ansible directly on the host.

I don't think we can dynamically add a host to the executor's inventory with a private key from a secret file?  If we could, it seems like the executor could just log itself into static.opendev.org and run jobs, and then publish the output.

The other option seems to be to write out a separate inventory, and run a nested Ansible from the executor like we do for system-config testing.  the "outer" job can then upload as usual.

this way the static host never has to write anything to AFS, which seems ideal.

but, in short, I'd like this spec to flesh out something like above so we have a agreed plan for publishing

I had imagined we would write the files outside of afs and then alias to them. That said I think the zuul job version of this would work fine as well. We'd need to inflate all the gzipped files then feed them to goaccess. deliverables/rocky/zun-tempest-plugin.ya.message:
this is old tag of 2.0.0 version. Tempest and plugins support stable branch with master version till they declare the un-support of that stable. and that release of un-support stable tag is used as stable-em tag not the one released during start of support of cycle release.

We can go with two option here:
1. use the last compatible commit hash for stable em tag. 0d639a465ea289781d5a3cb96fb283a85a284007 in case of zun-tempest-plugin which is before py2 drop.

2. keep the tempest plugins release same as tempest. Means Tempest or it plugins release the stable branch support and un-support explicitly in separate release once stable is EM or master is not compatible with EM stable anymore.

I prefer the 2nd one to syncup the release of all plugins with Tempest.

As the commit message mentions, you or the team would need to do another release if this is not the last point in the stable/rocky branch before going to extended maintenance. Rocky is now past the deadline for transitioning, so we would need that very soon.

The last point that stable/rocky was released would be the point it gets the rocky-em tag. From that point on, bugfixes may still be merged to the stable/rocky branch, but no more official tagging will be done off of it.

The team can also decide this branch is no longer going to be maintained and announce that, at which point there will be a six month period before it transitions to the end of life. That is the only point in the stable maintenance period where the latest commit on the branch, not the last release, is given a new tag of rocky-eol.

https://docs.openstack.org/project-team-guide/stable-branches.html#maintenance-phases

That is true for branched deliverables but Tempest and plugins are brachless. 

For branchless, we release the start of support and end of support of stable release is done separately with the corresponding commit from master not by the old tag done at release time of that stable branch which is nothing but the start of support of that release.  

For example, End of support of pike in Tempest is this - I971bc29e2ab12999c3384385a8c55a4ed0a3c361
Which is from master commit after which Tempest will not support Pike on master code. So pike end of support for Tempest is this tag not the one released at pike release(that was start of support of pike)

tripleo_common/actions/deployment.py.message:
this removes the unused services from the roles data file, which we then write back to the swift container.

then we more or less immediately deploy the stack directly with heat below.

however, i don't see anything that would update the templates/plan to actually take into account the updated roles data file.

in previous iterations of this patch, there was a 2nd call to the process templates action. I guess that's changed, but I'm not seeing how this has any effect anymore.

What do you mean "update the templates/plan to actually take into account the updated roles file"?  This just updates the ServicesDefault on the role file.  It's not until heat takes the files and processes them that has any effects around here.  As far as I can tell the ServicesDefault value is not consumed anywhere else in the templates prior to the stack creation/update.  Any query to ServicesDefault is done on the stack after heat has processed it so this sets up the plan update (e.g. pushing to swift) and then lets heat do its thing.  The rerunning of the templates was actually the problem with the previous patch because it would remove the services and they'd be there on the 2nd itteration but it wouldn't get put back.  We need to merge all the templates prior to inspecting the values for the resource registry.

Heat doesn't do anything with roles_data.yaml.

The contents of that file are never even passed to Heat. It's not even in the format of Heat template. So just updating that file in the plan does nothing. You have to update the file and re-process the templates.

ServicesDefault ends up as a parameter value in overcloud-resource-registry-puppet.yaml, and the value is read from roles_data.yaml and rendered into overcloud-resource-registry-puppet.yaml by jinja2.

Heat does not run jinja2. That is what process-templates.py does (and the process templates action).

Once the templates are rendered, then they are passed to Heat.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Your detailed commit message is appreciated, thank you!

This all makes sense but do you have any anecdotal data that making this change made an impact in your deployment? If so, it would be valuable to mention that in this commit message as well. We often rely on contributor's testing as it is not so easy for us to gather data for performance related improvements such as this.

I tested this out and noticed two things:

1. The performance of this resource update task has gotten way better in Train (and potentially Stein). I had originally filed the bug in Rocky and hadn't tested the original bug condition thoroughly again versus my fix. I had just tested that the fix didn't regress any other behavior. So this isn't as big of a deal as it used to be! I only saw the instances getting stuck for maybe 30 seconds to a minute.

2. Fair locks did improve things and from my tests the instance claim was able to obtain the lock more or less as it arrived.

So, maybe we can abandon this change. The question is, does it make sense to make Nova use fair locks everywhere? Or just in the resource tracker?

@melanie, sure--I have deployed it recently to a ~150 node deployment. I think I need to let it sit for a bit longer to make any claims as to how it impacts things. When I understand more about possible side effects I will update the request; I mostly wanted to get eyes on it early to see if there is any chance of the approach making it upstream, as I know it's a bit scary!

@Dan, you raise some good points, and I had to look over both nova's code and oslo service/lockutils to get a better idea of why I have seen what I've seen.

For context, the behavior I witnessed was that, if I was looking at logs, I would see a message about this periodic task starting. Then, I would see tons of messages slowly come in as all of the hosts were updating. At some point, my instance claim would arrive. This could take 20 minutes to an hour+ and seemed linear w/ the number of nodes; a 300-node cluster had ~2x delay than a ~150 node cluster.

Given that your sequence example makes total sense, I am wondering how I could see that. I looked through the oslo libraries and nova and noticed two things:

1. By default, lockutils locks are not "fair"; when the lock is released, a random thread waiting on the lock is selected to take the lock. It is not a first-in, first-out situation. So, with more things waiting on a lock, there is a relatively low probability a given task will be next to proceed, even if it arrived immediately after. Nova does not override the default "fair" kwarg.

2. From what I can tell, locks and greenthreads don't really mix very well. I can see there is some code to monkey-patch the threading libs such that they call greenthread under the hood, but from what I can tell, that monkey-patch is only applied when running tests. Is it possible that in a greenthread situation, and only one thread (as in nova-compute's case), lockutils is effectively not doing anything? It's hard to believe that. But at least in my nova-compute, for Ironic, there is only 1 thread.

So, I agree that under a sane threading situation, it doesn't gain much (although the not-fair locks are a bit of an issue). But perhaps this isn't a sane threading situation?

> 1. By default, lockutils locks are not "fair"; when the lock is
 > released, a random thread waiting on the lock is selected to take
 > the lock. It is not a first-in, first-out situation. So, with more
 > things waiting on a lock, there is a relatively low probability a
 > given task will be next to proceed, even if it arrived immediately
 > after. Nova does not override the default "fair" kwarg.

Hmm, okay, this would explain the behavior you see then. Obviously if the locks aren't fair then, as you say, the instance claim isn't going to be handled on the next iteration of the periodic (since it's the next thing waiting each time).

I know asyncio semaphores are fair, I dunno why ours aren't by default. If you pass the fair=True to @synchronized, does your delay go away?


 > 2. From what I can tell, locks and greenthreads don't really mix
 > very well. I can see there is some code to monkey-patch the
 > threading libs such that they call greenthread under the hood, but
 > from what I can tell, that monkey-patch is only applied when
 > running tests. Is it possible that in a greenthread situation, and
 > only one thread (as in nova-compute's case), lockutils is
 > effectively not doing anything? It's hard to believe that. But at
 > least in my nova-compute, for Ironic, there is only 1 thread.

No, we should be fully monkey-patched in nova compute:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/monkey_patch.py#L60

 > So, I agree that under a sane threading situation, it doesn't gain
 > much (although the not-fair locks are a bit of an issue). But
 > perhaps this isn't a sane threading situation?

We're not (real) threaded at all, as you say, and by design. The greenthreads do use the locks in order to handle thread switching around critical regions, there is just no actual *concurrency*.

But yes, the unfair-by-default is definitely why my sequence diagram isn't matching up with your experience. Can you try just setting fair=True and testing for us?

I think this is a fairly unique situation, specifically because nova wasn't designed to have this multiple node per compute host situation -- it was bolted on later. I would think that if you want to mark the RT lock fair in another change, that'd be an easy sell and then someone (you, if you're interested) could survey the rest. Just quickly thinking about it, I can't really think of any other places it would matter a whole lot, other than perhaps our build limit semaphores, which form somewhat of a queue. But even still, those are all "equal" in importance, so not as much of a "background task is starving real work" situation as this one.

I'm a little dubious about the gains, if any here. I know what you're going for and this combined with other changes may make some real gains. I think the only thing you accomplish by making this one change is potentially reducing some latency for a boot waiting for the semaphore while the periodic task finishes its update of some other node. So, the following sequence example for the single lock case:

1. Periodic task starts updating node12, under lock
2. A boot comes in targeted for node7, blocks on lock
3. Periodic task finishes node12, releases lock, loops around to node13
4. The boot is waiting in order, so it gets the lock, starts the boot on node7, then releases the lock
5. The periodic for loop gets granted the lock and goes on to update node13

So, there's some latency introduced between 2 and 3, which this would cut out, but since you only have to wait for one node update, it should be a pretty small amount of absolute time. Since we lock and unlock for each node as we roll through the RT nodes, the time to wait is not longer as the number of nodes increases.

In order to make the periodic actually do more work, we need a threadpool (and conf knob for the size) and a change to how we do the resource updates so that we delegate all the nodes to independent workers in the pool, let them lock on nodename and actually run in parallel, etc.

Depending on the situation, however, that may or may not actually help things. With a thousand ironic nodes on a single compute and a pool of decent size. It just means you're offering up a lot more resource to spend busy looping. On compute startup, that's worthwhile to reduce the time it takes to start up, but at steady-state, it's likely to be worthwhile. And, of course, ironic may or may not be able to actually handle that load faster in parallel. It would be a lot better to let nova shard the computes natively, as it can do, and reduce the burden on each compute service.

So, anyway, back to this change. In principle I guess this is not necessarily harmful (although I haven't reviewed in depth to decide if it's safe to do). However, unless I'm missing some other interaction you're improving here, I don't think it gains us much. What am I missing?

That sounds great Jason, thanks. I am aware of the problem of ironic deployments taking A Very Long Time (tm) to process as update because of the one to many mapping of nova-compute to ironic nodes + this particular lock and have long wondered if locking instead on hypervisor_hostname (ironic node name) would be a good way to solve it, but obviously that never happened.

So, I do wonder if there was a discussion and good reason we did not implement such a solution in the past, that I missed. I'm adding Dan Smith to this review as I think he's our best bet for recalling whether there was any past discussion around this upstream and any reason not to go ahead and do this.

I think this proposal makes sense otherwise and if there's no reason not to go ahead, I'd support making this change.

Does this work or are we just getting lucky? I always use NonCallableMock as:

with mock.patch(..., new_callable=mock.NonCallableMock())

I could see how this works though since it's the 'new' argument and NonCallableMock is a Mock, it's just...non-callable.

Well f me sideways.

I wrapped L708 in this same cm and it... doesn't fail. Using the new_callable kwarg makes it hit.

So I updated this one to do the same and... it also fails.

Investigating.
This was good for me to remind myself how all that worked, though. Lead away.

> So in order get this to work the same way as new=NonCallableMock(), you have to say: new_callable=NonCallableMock

Yeah sorry in my example I should have removed the parenthesis and I know that you pass the type rather than an instance of the type, so maybe I led you astray for awhile.

Turns out this does work as expected - I was just mocking the wrong thing: I missed that PlacementFixture is creating its own Adapter [1] rather than using (or patching) the one from the report client.

For completeness:

 new_callable=NonCallableMock()

breaks while it's actually doing the mocking - i.e. doesn't even get to the point where the mocked thing would be invoked. That's because the *value* of new_callable (in this case, the actual NonCallableMock instance) is *invoked* at *mock* time. It's typically used as a way to generate a mock dynamically.

So in order get this to work the same way as new=NonCallableMock(), you have to say

 new_callable=NonCallableMock

i.e. without the parens.

TL;DR: The value of 'new' is substituted for the mocked thing. The value of 'new_callable' is invoked, and the return value is substituted for the mocked thing.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/a2d7ffba32585cce3da2212edc026be66d4ede66/nova/tests/functional/fixtures.py#L75

Perhaps we can simply state that our modules work with any non-EOL OpenStack API versions?

We actually don't care of the API is EOL, we still support it. It's phrased in terms of public clouds because those are the ones as developers we can actually verify against - and are one of the reasons this is a design point. Just because upstream openstack has marked a release EOL doesn't mean there aren't clouds out there still running it. Our users are the users of the APIs of those clouds and it's not their fault that their cloud provider hasn't upgraded.

Also, some users of those clouds are also users of modern up to date clouds and to handle multi cloud workloads, they need to be able to have one copy of ansible that works against all of their clouds (not an invented use case, I'm describing openstack-infra)

All that said - we could certainly phrase this differently. Do you think it would be useful to say some version of that whole thing above?

We should maybe add a bullet point:

* Most logic should go into the cloud layer of openstacksdk leaving modules themselves to be primarily glue-code providing appropriate ansible interfaces. If logic is needed for handling some sort of OpenStack object, it stands to reason that the same logic would be useful to other openstack users.
This bullet point can go away.

Oh - it just used to be a chicken and egg when this was all in the ansible repo. You're exactly right - we have integration tests for sdk - and now that the collection is over here in gerrit land and gated by the same zuul - we can actually just flat out make some co-gate jobs.

How does this make a chicken-and-egg scenario? The OpenStackSDK (the egg) is tested via it's own Python integration/unit tests. The Ansible modules (the chicken) would presumably have their own separate tests. It would even be possible to add Molecule testing to the modules for functional testing. History of this part of code:
The original code come from changes applied in python-memcached (1.54) who introduced a call to super in the __init__ of the memcache.Client, but this class inherit from threading.local and at start they try to remove the original parents (threading.local) from the inheritance hierarchy but doesn't work due to the usage of super in __init__.

Threading.local define the following attributes:
* __new__
* __getattribute__
* __setattr__
* __delattr__

So I suppose if we facing issues with __new__ we potentially can facing others issues with the other methods too, so I think we need to redefine them properly.
